title: Vitamin D3 in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

producedBy.name: Vitamin D3 in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

affiliations.name: Feinstein Institute for Medical Research NS-LIJ Health System

usesReagent.name: SuperScript III RNase H  Reverse Transcriptase

values: Subject has provided written informed consent.
Subject is >= 18 years of age.
Meets at least 4 of 11 modified American College of Rheumatology (ACR) 1982 Revised Criteria for the Classification of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus as updated in 1997.
Serum 25-OH vitamin D level less than or equal to 20 ng/mL.
Stable disease at Screening, defined as a modified SELENA SLEDAI <= 4.

Interferon signature present. Determination of the IFN alpha signature will be assessed by measuring expression levels of 3 IFN alpha responsive genes, Mx1, Ifit1, and Ifi44 using RT-PCR in mRNA extracted from PBMCs. The mean and standard deviation for normal controls is determined for each gene. The signature is present if one of the 3 genes is expressed at a level greater than or equal to 4 standard deviations above the mean of normal controls or if 2 of the 3 genes are expressed more than 2 standard deviations above the mean of normal controls.
Positive anti-dsDNA antibody at the time of screening.
If on corticosteroids, the dose must be < 20mg per day and stable for the 4 weeks prior to screening and at baseline.

If on immunosuppressive or immunomodulatory medication such as azathioprine, methotrexate, leflunomide, mycophenolate, or hydroxychloroquine, the dose must be stable for the 3 months prior to screening and baseline, and expected to remain stable over the course of the study.
If taking a multivitamin or a vitamin D supplement, the dose of vitamin D must be less than or equal to 800 IU daily and stable for the 3 months prior to screening and at baseline.
Males and females with reproductive potential must agree to practice effective measures of birth control.
History of receiving any multivitamin, supplement, or drug containing more than 800 IU daily of vitamin D within the last 3 months.
Unwillingness to stop using drugs or substances that interfere with or may interfere with fat absorption (e.g., Orlistat).
Hypercalcemia (serum calcium > 10.4 mg/dl) at screening.
Hypercalciuria (urinary calcium/creatinine ratio = 0.8) at screening.
History of hyperparathyroidism.
History of renal stones.
History of cancer, except cervical carcinoma in situ and resected basal and squamous cell carcinomas of the skin.
Known history of chronic viral infections, including HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C.
Known active tuberculosis.
Any BILAG A or B manifestation with the exception of a BILAG B mucocutaneous manifestation.
ALT or AST = 2x upper limit of normal.
Dialysis or serum creatinine > 1.5 mg/dl.
Expectation by the investigator to increase corticosteroid or immunosuppressive, or immunomodulatory medication dose at screening, baseline, or over the course of the study.
Current treatment with cyclophosphamide or a biologic.
Treatment with cyclophosphamide within 3 months prior to screening.
Treatment with rituximab within the 12 months prior to screening.

Other Investigational drug and/or treatment during the 4 weeks or seven half-lives of the other investigational drug prior to the start of study drug dosing (Day 0), whichever is the greater length of time.
Drug or alcohol abuse within 6 months prior to randomization.
Pregnancy or lactation.
Treatment with digoxin.
Treatment with teriparatide (Forteo).
Any condition that, in the opinion of the Investigator, would jeopardize the subject?s safety following exposure to the study drug.

affiliations.name: Feinstein Institute for Medical Research NS-LIJ Health System

creators.name: EFFECT OF VITAMIN D3 ON THE IFNA SIGNATURE IN PATIENTS WITH LUPUS (ALE02)

values.value: This multi-center double-blind placebo controlled trial will investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on the interferon signature in patients with systemic lupus erythrematosus. Vitamin D deficient patients with spell out who possess the interferon signature will be randomized to receive 0, 2000 or 4000 IU/daily of cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) for 12 weeks. Potential clinical effects as well as safety will be assessed and monitored

primaryPublications.authorsList: Aranow C(1), Kamen DL(2), Dall'Era M(3), Massarotti EM(4), Mackay MC(1), Koumpouras F(5), Coca A(6), Chatham WW(7), Clowse ME(8), Criscione-Schreiber LG(8), Callahan S(9), Goldmuntz EA(9), Keyes-Elstein L(10), Oswald M(1), Gregersen PK(1), Diamond B(1).
primaryPublications.title: Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of the Effect of Vitamin D3 on the Interferon Signature in Patients With Systemic Lupus Erythematosus.

availability: Available for download after registration with ImmPort

distributions.title: Vitamin D3 in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

acknowledges.name: EFFECT OF VITAMIN D3 ON THE IFNA SIGNATURE IN PATIENTS WITH LUPUS (ALE02)

description: This is a double-blind, multi-center, placebo controlled, Phase II study designed to assess biologic effects of 12 weeks of vitamin D3 supplementation on patients with well-controlled stable systemic lupus erythematosus who have low serum levels of 25-OH vitamin D and an IFN alpha signature.
